testimony: Good morning everybody.   Mr Van der Merwe?
Thank you Judge, we are ready to proceed.
Thank you, you may be seated.

Thank you Mr Chairman.   Mr Chairman, the Committee will note that there is an amnesty application for Mr Baker in Volume 1, filed at pages 91 to 112.  This was actually done in mistake, the improved application is filed in Volume 2 and from page 139.  They are in essence the same, I think the second one is just an improved version.  For practical purposes, I would suggest that we ignore the first one and deal with the application on page 139 of Volume 2.
Yes, thank you.   I will proceed then.  Mr Baker, do you confirm that you have applied for amnesty in this regard as per the Annexure, Form 1, from page 139 onwards in Volume 2, is that correct?
Sorry, I think - sorry, thank you.

Thank you Mr Chairman.   I am not going to bear the Committee with all the background information, do you confirm the information contained and given to this Committee from page 139 right up to page 154, which is your background?

I would like to just point to one incident which might help this Committee with regard to the times that these incidents took place in.  On page 146 of your application, you indicate there that in 1986 you were injured in a limpet mine attack which was placed by Christopher Gordon Webster and Robert McBride in which one of your colleagues, Lt-Col Wellman was eventually killed as a result of that explosion, is that correct?
And that is also the direct cause for which you suffer hearing problems at this stage of your life?  Is that correct?
As far as you are concerned and as far as you know, nobody has come forward to apply for amnesty in that matter, is that correct?

Thank you.  Let us proceed to your application itself.  Mr Chair, the application from page 155 onwards, there is however just one correction we would like to make, on page 157 the last sentence of that first paragraph should read
"... I accept that the concealment of the body (it should be body, it should be death)."
Do you confirm that Mr Baker?

Mr Baker, if you can then start for us, you are in this incident applying for amnesty for any crime or delict relating to the death of Nthombi Khubeka in which we will also include the abduction and possible assault of Nthombi Khubeka, is that correct?
Through common purpose, yes, that is correct Mr Chairman.
You are not exactly sure of the date of this incident, is that correct?
Do you accept the dates that were given here and will be led by that, is that correct?
I accept that, that is correct Mr Chairman.
Right, can you start reading for us at paragraph 4 of your application please.

I was a Captain in the South African Police, second in command of Section C1, Vlakplaas.   I was visiting our operational team in Durban, who were based in the facility near Amanzimtoti from which the teams were operating.  The team fell under the command of the South African Police Security Branch Divisional Headquarters at the area where they were deployed.  In this instance, they fell under the command of Capt Henti Botha and Gen Steyn of the ...(indistinct) Security Branch.  A safehouse used by trained MK cadres infiltrating from Swaziland, had been identified in kwaMashu.  An askari, Jimmy Mbane, posing as an MK cadre had infiltrated the facility which was run by an old woman, unknown to me.   Members of her family were Umkhonto weSizwe members and she was a loyal ANC supporter.  The purpose of the operation was to arrest four MK members who were to infiltrate from Swaziland and report at the facility.  The askari had to determine when they would arrive. After six weeks the cadres had not arrived and the askari's version of events was being questioned by Capt Botha.   The askari, still pretending to be an MK member, met with her and she was apprehended by Capt Botha and his team and brought to our base near Amanzimtoti.
If I could just interpose here.  This paragraph, this is obviously information that you got from somewhere, can you just help us with that.  Where did you hear it or who did you get it from?
This information was given to me by Col Taylor.
That was the afternoon that I arrived at the facility and which is the same afternoon, or evening, that Ms Khubeka was brought to the facility.
Sorry, Mr Baker, in this paragraph you say that "the facility was run by an old woman, unknown to me", is that in fact, are you talking about the deceased?
That is correct Mr Chairman, I was told that it was an old woman.
Were you told that she was an old woman, because it would seem that, well that she was not an old woman in that she was approximately roundabout 40 years of age.
But your information was that she was an old woman?

Yes, that was an old woman.  I was present at the base.  During the questioning by Capt Botha, I went in and out to establish whether there was any information on the four MK cadres.   Later Capt Botha informed me that she had died apparently from a heart attack.  Capt Botha decided that her body should be removed and placed elsewhere, the purpose was to prevent the secret facility being identified and further to prevent the ANC from learning that their safehouse had been exposed.   He also did not want to link the investigation by the South African Police as this would have seriously jeopardised the covert operation.  I had no role in her questioning and the subsequent removal of her body.   Since I assumed that Capt Botha would have discussed the matter further with his superior, Gen Steyn, I did not take any action myself.  I accept that the concealment of her death, prevented the investigation of her death according to laid down procedures.

Right, if I can just take you back to page 156, the last paragraph, you indicate that at one stage you went in and out to establish whether there was any information on the four MK cadres, you then carry on to say "later Capt Botha informed me", were you present at the base for the whole period?
No Mr Chairman, I was not.
Can you just tell the Committee what happened, if you went anywhere?
As I recall, I accompanied Lt at that stage, du Preez, to go and fetch, to go and buy food for my people who were at the base.
Right.    Lt du Preez, were you in his company at all, until the time that you left to go and buy food or do you not know where he was at that stage?
As I can recall, I left with him and returned with him.
No, before you left with him, you don't know where he was, is that correct?
Did you participate in these events for any personal gain?
No I did not Mr Chairman.
Were your actions in this operation driven by spite or malice?
Do you then also confirm the rest of your application, right until page 161 of the Bundle, is that correct?
Therefore you are asking this Committee to grant you amnesty for your involvement in this whole incident as you have described to the Committee?
If the Chair will just bear with me for a moment.   Let's just deal with the assault, when you entered this - let me rephrase this, were you at any stage aware of any assaults on the late Ms Khubeka?
Can you just indicate to the Committee what your awareness was, what your observations were?

What I remember is that a person had a black plastic object in his hand and on poking my head around the door of this room, on a couple of occasions, Capt Botha would inform me of what was going on, whether there was any information regarding further procedures that we would have to take and then I would withdraw, but on being outside the room, I heard blows.
You in other words are saying that you never actually physically saw anyone assaulting her, but it was quite clear from what you heard, that she was being assaulted during the interrogation?

Then just a little bit of background for the Committee's sake, you came down, can you recall how long you were in the Durban area when this incident took place, for how many days had you been here already at that stage?

As I recall, I had come down - there was the team working with the Intelligence component and there was a bigger team working on general information, I had come to visit both teams and as far as I can recall, I had been in the area for a couple of days with the other team.
You were however, not directly involved with this operation of Capt Botha at all, is that correct?
Your black members of Vlakplaas, the askaris, where were they put up, where did they stay?
Generally the black members stayed at the Dog Unit and also the white members stayed at the Dog Unit at C.R. Swart Square.

Just for the assistance of the Committee, Sgt Joe Coetzer was what they would have referred to as the Officer in Charge of the three black members referred to in this application which would be Dube, Radebe and Mbane, is that correct?
Joe Coetzer was the white team leader and the black team leader was Warrant Officer Radebe.  That is of this specific team.

Thank you Mr Chair.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VAN DER MERWE
Thank you Mr van der Merwe.  Mr Visser, do you have any questions you would like to put to the witness?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Baker, as I understand it, Mr Eugene de Kock became the Commander of Vlakplaas round or about July of 1986, would that be correct?
No Mr Chairman, as far as I know, it was in 1985.
I am sorry, 1985, yes.  And he was still the Commander of the C1 Unit, Vlakplaas, in 1987?
Who was his second in command?
I was second in command, Mr Chairman.
And was there a third in command?
There were other officers, but at that stage the command structure was such that he was overall in command, and I was his second in command, Mr Chairman.
Second in command?    Can I ask you whether you recall Mr Frank McCarter being a member of Vlakplaas in 1987?
Sorry, could you just repeat that name please, Mr Visser?
I am going to spell it, Mr Frank M-c-C-a-r-t-e-r.
That is also correct Mr Chairman.

The reason why I am asking you this is to ask you this following question, and that is can you recall, you say that there were two teams, there was the bigger team and then the team consisting of the three gentlemen that are involved in this amnesty application in Durban at the time of the Khubeka incident?
Can you recall whether these persons that I mentioned to you, were also here at the time?
Mr Chairman, my recollection is that Mr McCarter was here with the team, I wouldn't know who all the members of his team were at that stage, but they could have been.
Yes, all right.  And you stated that you slept or you stayed at the Dog Unit at C.R. Swart Square or the team stayed there?
He said generally they would stay there.
Yes, so generally you would stay there.  Can you remember at this particular time of the Khubeka incident, where you had slept?

Mr Chairman, I slept at the Dog Unit and on this particular day, I had gone down to speak to Col Taylor and to discuss the teams and their deployment and I slept that night at the facility at Winkelspruit.
Can I ask you this, would it be fair to say that there was a lot of violence in the Durban area in 1987?
Would you remember whether you had been to Durban in 1987 on more than one occasion?

I will tell you why, because in another incident which had, which was dealt with in November last year, here in Durban, before his Lordship, Justice Wilson, that is the matter if Sipho Stanley Bhila, sorry Mr Chairman, I didn't notice that you were talking to somebody, S-i-p-h-o Stanley Bhila, the evidence was by Mr McCarter that a team from Vlakplaas had come down to Durban on the 10th of February and stayed until the 27th of February, 17 odd days?  Would you know about that, can you recall it today?
No Mr Chairman, I cannot recall it.  Teams were sent down on a regular basis, I know, because of the situation prevailing in Port Natal.

All right, well, then just through you to inform the Committee, you don't necessarily have to reply to this, I can tell you that from the evidence and what was put there, Mr Radebe was also here during that period of time, the 10th to the 27th of February.  As I say, if you cannot remember, I am just informing the Committee through you.   Mr Baker, you heard the evidence of the other applicants, Botha, Wasserman, du Preez and van der Westhuizen, is that correct?
Is there any material aspect of their evidence with which you did not agree?
Mr Chairman, as far as the sleeping aspects are concerned, I recall that Joe Coetzer and the team went back to C.R. Swart that evening after this unfortunate incident.

Would you recall who of the Vlakplaas persons all went back to the C.R. Swart Dog Unit, perhaps I could make it easier by asking you the reverse.  Can you recall today whether any of the members, apart from yourself, stayed at Winkelspruit on that fateful evening?
They all went back, it was only myself that stayed Mr Chairman.  That is my recollection.
You see, because on behalf of Mr Mbane it has been stated and it has been put to the witnesses that he slept there that evening?
My recollection is that they all went back, Mr Chairman.

Yes, be that as it may, assuming for a moment that you might be mistaken, and that he might have slept there, that is Mr Jimmy Mbane, what is your recollection of someone sleeping right in front of the store room door where Ms Khubeka was being interrogated?
Mr Chairman, I do not remember anybody sleeping there.
It is a bit hard on the cement there.
Do you think that you might have remembered it if there had been somebody sleeping there?
If there had been, I would have.
Given the circumstances of what was going on there?
If there had been people there, I think I should have remembered it.
Sorry Mr Visser, just in case you may be giving the wrong impression to the witness, it is not being suggested that Mr Mbane was sleeping there during the interrogation at all.
Mr Chairman, with great respect, that is exactly what was put because he says the door was opened, he saw inside and he saw an assault going on.
No, he said that he slept that night in the verandah, I think we agreed to call it the verandah.

The point I am making with the greatest of respect is that there has been no suggestion at the time the interrogation was taking place, he was sleeping there?  He was in the vicinity, but it is not that he was actually sleeping?
Oh, I see it is a question of the sleeping?

All right, I stand corrected Mr Chairman.    Let us confine ourselves then to sleeping there at any stage on the evening, that evening when Ms Khubeka was being interrogated there, on that evening, and I am not thereby suggesting as Mr Lax has corrected me, to say that it was while the interrogation was going on, but at any stage during that evening, while you went in there to go and find out whether information had been obtained from Ms Khubeka, did you see anybody sleeping on that what we refer to as the verandah?

Incidentally, did you obtain that evening or subsequent to the death of Ms Khubeka, any information regarding the four MK members that this whole operation was about, that might have been obtained from her?
No Mr Chairman.  As a result of this incident, the Intelligence operation regarding, or our involvement in the Intelligence operation was terminated a day or two afterwards.

Yes.   Yes.  At page 155 of Volume 2 of the Bundles, in the last sentence on that page you say
"... in this instance the team fell under the command of Capt H. Botha and Gen Steyn of Durban."
	I noticed that you don't mention the name of Col Andy Taylor there, is there a specific reason for that?

Mr Chairman, yes, Capt Botha was in charge of Intelligence Units, the MK Intelligence Unit.   This operation was basically his, but the overall deployment of the greater team if I can call it as such, actually fell under Col Taylor.  I had been there to find out about the deployment of the greater team.

Yes, that is how I understand it, all right.  At page 156, can I just clarify this with you, it appears that you agree with the evidence of the previous witnesses that the purpose of the operation was to get that four MK members that had infiltrated into the Republic of South Africa, page 156 Mr Chairman, it is about one third down the page.
Yes, or who were to infiltrate, I am not putting too fine a point on that, but it had to do with four terrorists?

And then later on in the same paragraph, you seem to suggest that the intention was that Ms Khubeka was to be apprehended and you say
"... the askari, and you are referring to Jimmy Mbane, still pretending to be an MK member, met with her and she was apprehended."
	Did you intend with those words to say that that was the purpose of the operation on that day, that she was to be arrested?
Mr Chairman, as told to me by Capt Botha after she had been apprehended, he said that Mbane had met her and she had been apprehended.  I don't know if that was the intention of the operation.
Yes, the question I was going to ask you was simply this, did you know what the instructions of Mbane was as to what he had to do on that particular day?

Would it fit in with your understanding of the situation at the time, if I put to you that Botha had informed him or had instructed him to attempt to bring at least the Commander of the MK Units, to a particular place at Battery Beach, would that coincide with your understanding of the whole operation?
You also told the Committee that you went in and out and at a certain point in time, you saw a person in the room where Ms Khubeka was being questioned, with a plastic object.
I think a black object he said.
A black plastic object in his hand, was this a round object, a square object, elongated object, what did you think it was?
Mr Chairman, my recollection was that it looked like a piece of black hose-pipe, in other words round.
Yes, and was the person that you saw, was he doing anything with it?
Mr Chairman, when I opened the door, people in the room would look at me.
Mr Chairman, there is a first for everybody, I do really apologise  I am terribly sorry Mr Chairman.
I think it happens to all of us, Mr Visser.
It even happened to Constitution Justice Kriegler, so I am in good company Mr Chairman.  I have now lost my train of thought.
We are talking about, Mr Baker said it looked like a piece of black hose-pipe to him.
Thank you Mr Chairman.   And you were telling us what you saw, whether you saw this person do anything with that piece of black what appeared to you like hose-pipe?
Mr Chairman, what would happen, when I opened the door, the people in the room would look up at who was coming in obviously.
Yes.  And would they then stop with whatever they were doing?
Yes, they would stop and look at me, and as I said I would just ask is anything positive and negative and I walked out.  This happened a couple of times.
Yes.   What I want to ask you is, can you recall who the person was that you saw with this black object in his hand?
You cannot recall?   Mr Joe Coetzer, what is your recollection of him being present or not at any time during that late afternoon, early evening?
Mr Chairman, my recollection is that Joe Coetzer was at the base.

He was there?   You also stated at page 156, the second paragraph on that page
"... during the questioning of Capt Botha, I went in and out to establish whether there was any information on the four MK cadres."
	Now, you heard the evidence of Botha and of Wasserman and van der Westhuizen in this regard, how certain are you that Capt Botha was the person who questioned her?
Mr Chairman, I do not know who was questioning her, I would ask Capt Botha if there was any positive information.
What you are really, the point you are really making here is that Botha was reporting to you whether something was coming out or not?
Not primarily that he was the one questioning?

I have no further questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER
Thank you Mr Visser.  Mr Nel, do you have any questions that you would like to ask the witness?
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Baker, do you know Spyker Myeza?
Did you see Spyker Myeza at Winkelspruit base on this day of the incident?
No Mr Chairman, as far as I know, he was with the other team.

Thank you sir.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR NEL
Thank you.  Ms Botha, do you have any questions?  Mr Hugo, sorry?

3Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Baker, I just want to get some clarity on the command structures whenever Vlakplaas groups were deployed in an area for instance like Durban.  What were the structures like taking it from the bottom upwards, maybe I should put it differently.  There were groups of askaris that were allocated to a group leader, is that correct?
And the group leader would be normally a black policeman?
And to whom would this group leader then in turn report?
To a white group leader Mr Chairman.
And what would the rank normally be of that white group leader?
Mr Chairman, the ranks were between Sergeant and Lieutenant.
Yes, and I take it there would then in turn be a Coordinator to whom this particular person would be reporting to?
Yes, that is correct Mr Chairman.
And during this incident, can you remember who the different groups were, or let me just put it differently, how many askari groups were deployed here in Durban?
Mr Chairman, as far as I can remember, it was one group and then the Intelligence group if I can refer to the two different ...
Are you referring to the group that we are concerned with, as the Intelligence group?
Yes, that is helping with Intelligence operation, Mr Chairman.
So you had two different groups of askari's that were not working together in Durban at that time?
One of which was the Intelligence group of which Mr Mbane was one of the members?
Let's concentrate on this particular group, Mr Mbane was one of the members, who were the other members of this group?

Mr Chairman, as far as I can remember, I remember Mr Radebe and I have heard here that Mr Dube was also there, that is however not my recollection, I could not remember him being here, but there was a third person.
But you can recall that Mr Radebe was the leader of this particular group?
And to whom was he reporting to?
And Sgt Coetzer would report to?
So they wouldn't report to you as the second in charge of the Vlakplaas contingent?

I was not involved in the operation, I came down as I say to visit the teams and that particular day, I arrived at the facility.  From there, Sgt Coetzer would have spoken to me and I would have spoken to Capt Botha obviously.
Is it also true that these different groups were each allocated, well in most instances, a vehicle or a kombi?
That is correct Mr Chairman, Mr Radebe had a kombi.
Can you remember what the colour of this kombi was at the time?
Can you remember what sort of kombi it was?
Either the make of it or the type? Was it like a taxi or what?
Mr Chairman, yes, like a taxi.  It could have been a Mitsubishi, it could have been a Hi-Ace kombi, it could have been a Nissan, Nissan also still made kombi's in those days.
You say like a taxi in that it was a passenger vehicle?

Was it normal procedure for askaris to liaise directly with say the white Commanders or would they go through the group leader, being in this particular instance, Mr Radebe, when information was obtained?
Normally what they would do is go through the group leaders, I however at this instance, don't know exactly how the operation was run, if they were spoken to individually or together.
Can I just ask you, how long - well prior to this incident, how long were you in Durban for?
My recollection is that I had come down a couple of days beforehand.
Can you recall what Mr Radebe was doing at the time when you arrived here?
I am not sure exactly what you ...
Well, I am referring to this group that was under the command of Mr Radebe, when you arrived in Durban, what operation was he busy with at the time?
They were involved with the Intelligence operation with Capt Botha.
And were they working on this particular matter?
They were working as far as I can recall, solely on this matter.
Then something else, did you have any contact with informers and when I say informers, I am once more referring to this particular incident, whilst you were here, down in Durban?
You must have heard that mention was made of an informer whose leg was put in plaster of paris at some stage, did you have any knowledge of that?
Mr Chairman, I heard about it here at this hearing.

Yes.   And then I just want you to go to page 156, this is Bundle 2, just the last sentence in the first paragraph, it says
"... the askari, still pretending to be an MK member, met with her and she was apprehended by Capt Botha and his team and brought to our base near Amanzimtoti."
	Mr Visser has already asked you, you got this information from Mr Botha, is that correct?
Sorry, I made a mistake, from Taylor while I was at the base.
With respect, I was puzzled by that when you asked the question, you said Botha.

Absolutely, I agree with you, but when you asked the question, you said Botha and I made a note of that to ask him about it later, that is why I am correcting what you are saying.  You actually said Botha and I made a note of that because it was different to his evidence-in-chief.
I am just trying to be of assistance to show that he said Taylor as well, Mr Chairman.

No fair enough, but the point is he spoke to Taylor when he got to the base, that was his evidence-in-chief, however you asked him about speaking to Botha about the nature of the operation and you also asked him about Radebe's, at least Mbane's instructions in that context, you will recall, and at that stage, the clear focus of your questions was Botha, not Taylor.
No, no, there is no question about that.

Be it as it may, Mr Baker, for our purposes, it is more important to find out whether you are clear in your mind that reference was made to an askari and not askaris.  Mr Chairman, I recall it as an askari.  When the group arrived at Winkelspruit after Ms Khubeka had been handed over, did you see them arriving there?  Sorry, I may also not be all that clear, I am referring to the group led by Mr Botha?

No Mr Chairman.  My recollection is when the group arrived, I was sitting in that as they described yesterday, that enclosed portion where the sleeping quarters were, I was sitting there discussing, having a discussion with Mr Taylor about the deployment of the groups and I heard a vehicle pull up, but at that stage I didn't see the vehicle.
Was it only one vehicle that you heard?
That is my recollection at that stage, that only one vehicle came immediately.
And was there another vehicle that arrived later?
By whom was this vehicle driven?
Mr Chairman, I am not sure, I did not see that vehicle.  I just heard the vehicle arrive.
Yes, and the passengers, didn't you see them?
is it possible that this vehicle could have been driven by Mr Radebe and the other passengers being Mr Dube and Mr Mbane?
Did you at all see them there that evening?
Yes Mr Chairman, they were there.
As far as I can recall, my recollection is that Mr Radebe and I presume the other members who were sitting in the kombi, relaxing.
Were they in a position to see what was going on in that little room where the interrogation took place?
I am not sure Mr Chairman, I am not sure where the kombi was parked.

Yes.  What was Mr Joe Coetzer's role, well, let me rather try and confine my question.  Did Mr Joe Coetzer from time to time leave the interrogation room to go and speak to the black members, being Mr Mbane, Dube and Radebe?
Mr Chairman, I do not recall that, I do not recall Mr Coetzer being in the interrogation room either.
Sorry, Mr Baker, did you keep a continuous watch on that vehicle in which you saw Mr Radebe and other members?
No Mr Chairman, I left the base with Lt du Preez, so for that period I don't know what happened.
Yes, but even while you were there, did you keep ...
No, I did not keep a continuous watch.
So it is possible that people from time tome could have got out of that kombi, walked around,got back in, that Mr Coetzer may have spoken to them or may not and you just didn't see it?
And then after the incident, did you report to Mr Eugene de Kock as to what happened?
That is correct Mr Chairman, not immediately after, I think it was the following day that I made telephonic contact with him and informed him.
I informed him that there had been an unfortunate incident where the person had died, and that this operation would be terminated as a result of the people not being able to carry on with it.
You didn't tell him that an offence had been committed, you just said it was an unfortunate incident?
I told him that she had died and that they said that she died of a heart attack.
And Mr de Kock, was he in Durban  or did he come down to Durban before you left for Pretoria?
Mr Chairman, I am not sure.  My recollection is that I had telephoned him.  If he had been in Durban, I presume I would have seen him personally.

I have no further questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR HUGO
Thank you Mr Hugo.  Mr Samuel, do you have any questions that you would like to ask?
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Baker, what time did you get to the Winkelspruit base?
Mr Chairman, as far as I recollect, it was in the afternoon.
Were any vehicles at the base at the time when you arrived?
Mr Taylor's vehicle was there and there were other vehicles standing around, I am not sure which vehicles were there.
Where was Mr du Preez at that time?
He was not present Mr Chairman.
When Mr du Preez and Mr Botha arrived on the scene, were you present?
Mr Chairman, I was speaking to Col Taylor in the sleeping facility when the vehicle arrived.
Did you see them arrive sir?
How do you know where you were at the time?
I was at the base in the sleeping facility, one could hear a vehicle arrive Mr Chairman.
How long after that, after the vehicle arrived, did you approach the vehicle, or did you approach that vehicle?
Mr Chairman, as far as I can recall, it was not very long after the vehicle had arrived that I went out and then saw that there was, well, that the people were in this room.
May I just come in here, sorry, didn't you know that the people were in the room?
Walking out, Mr Chairman, walking out of the sleeping facility which was closed off from the front, I walked around it and the voices were coming from the room.
But at what time did Taylor leave you?
On the arrival of the vehicle, if I am not mistaken, Capt Botha came to call him.
And you didn't know why he called him and where to he had called him?
Well, I presumed when Capt Botha came to him and they walked around the corner, that they had possibly apprehended people because they said they were waiting to apprehend people.
But didn't Botha say anything to Taylor in particular that you ...
No, not in my presence, he just called him.
Sorry Chair, if I may, you were sitting in that room, speaking to Taylor?
I think it is the sleeping quarters.
The concrete slab with the tarpaulin.
Yes, let's call it a concrete based tent, because that is more or less what it was.
And how long had you been sitting there for, talking to him?
Mr Chairman, it was - I don't know exactly what time I got there, it could have been an hour, an hour or two.  I am not sure how long it was.
Yes, so it was quite some time.
We had been sitting, discussing for some time, yes.
And what did Taylor tell you, what were you talking about?

Mr Chairman, we were talking about, I had gone there to find out specifically if the teams, if he was happy with the way the teams were working, and where they could be deployed further because he was in charge of Port Natal C-Section, which is the Terrorist Section, and it was quite a large area which stretched I think from the Transkei to the Tugela and we were discussing the deployment of the team, which areas would be most likely for them to find returned terrorists.
You were also discussing why he was there and why he called you there?  You had gone there to meet him?
I had gone to see him, yes.
Yes, you knew he was there, you had gone there to meet him?
So you must have spoken to him before that, and known that he was there?
Yes, I had contacted him, as far as I remember, I didn't know how to get to the facility and he had met me off the highway.
Correct.  Now, he must have told you why he was waiting there?
Mr Chairman, as I referred to, he told me about this operation as well, that they were waiting to apprehend these terrorists.
Yes, so when the vehicle arrived, he must have been waiting for them to arrive?
Mr Chairman, yes, he was obviously waiting for them to come.
Yes, so didn't both of you get up to go and see what had happened?
No, I don't recall my getting up immediately.

You see, it strikes me as somewhat strange, you are both waiting there, you are waiting there for these chaps to arrive, you know that they have gone on an operation to arrest terrorists, when a vehicle finally does arrive, you don't get up to see what is going on, you just carry on talking?

Mr Chairman, as I said, it could have been a matter, it was a short period of time,  it is also possible I could have showered and been dressing as well, at that time.  I used to sleep there that night, so I can't remember exactly the detail what happened at that stage.

Yes, it just seems to me that if you, and if you are expecting people to come in from an operation where people are going to be picked up, and these are the people the whole operation has been about, you are expecting that and you guys just carry on, sitting there until somebody calls you, that seems with respect, somewhat strange.
No, Mr Chairman, I don't think it wasn't a matter of minutes before Capt Botha came to Col Taylor, it was probably as they had stopped, he probable came straight to where he was.
Thank you Mr Chairman.   Did you see Ms Khubeka when she got off the vehicle?
When was the first time you saw Ms Khubeka?
When I poked my head around the door, Mr Chairman.
How long after you arrived, was that?
I would say it could have been a matter of minutes.
Did you notice anything about her, anything unusual or usual, may I rephrase that Chair, did you notice anything about Ms Khubeka?
All I noticed was that she was a large woman.

Is there anything else?  Before you answer Mr Baker, you are making an application for amnesty, I believe one of the bases for that application would be to tell the truth and to the best of your recollection, tell this Commission what you had seen, am I correct?
Did you see Ms Khubeka blindfolded?
Why didn't you tell the Chairman about that, I asked you now what did you notice about Ms Khubeka?
Mr Chairman, with due respect, I wasn't asked to give a description, he just said what did you notice about her.
Isn't that something noticeable that you should have brought to the attention of this Commission?
Well, I have done so Mr Chairman, on your question.

Is there anything else that you want to tell us about this incident sir, before we start cross-examining you on issues, each issue so that you can tell the truth and the Commission will know exactly what you saw?  Is there anything that you have missed out so far?
Mr Chairman, with all due respect, I don't think this is a proper question, if my learned colleague wants to ask him something ...
I think you can cross-examine, you can ask the questions.
Thank you Mr Chairman.   Mr du Preez, sorry, Mr Botha ...
No, third time lucky, Mr Baker.
Mr Baker, you say that you saw Ms Khubeka for a few minutes and thereafter, what happened?
Mr Chairman, I did not say that I saw her for a few minutes.
He said he saw her a few minutes or a couple of minutes I am not sure what term was used, after the arrival, yes.
And you noticed her thereafter, am I right, after her arrival, you saw her thereafter?
That is correct Mr Chairman, when I poked my head around the door.
She was alive at that stage?
And you also told this Commission you saw someone with a black plastic object in their hand?
Now, could you tell this Commission how that was possible if you had gone with Mr du Preez to buy food for your members?
Mr Chairman, I said that I had poked my head around the door a couple of times to find out if there was any work that we could proceed on, before departing with Mr du Preez.
If I, I will refer you to page 3, paragraph 12 of Mr du Preez' statement.
Sorry, are you referring to the Exhibits?

In this, have you got that?  According to Mr du Preez, he says
"... as soon as, after I had delivered Khubeka to Col Taylor and Col Botha ..."
Sorry, my Afrikaans is not all that strong, but "nadat", you interpret it as "as soon as".
Be that as it may, I will accept that.

I will accept that, and it was his evidence before this Commission sir, in line with that statement, in line with paragraph 12 that after he had handed Ms Khubeka to Col Taylor and Col Botha, he had departed immediately - so we understood?
Mr Chairman, as far as I can see, I do not see that he said that he left immediately.
We shouldn't get into semantics, but "nadat" does not necessarily mean immediately.  It may have a wider meaning, one should look at it in the context perhaps.
As the Chairman pleases.  Sir, are you saying, where was Mr du Preez after he had handed Ms Khubeka to Col Botha, do you recall?
Mr Chairman, I cannot recall where he was exactly at that stage.
Did you notice whether he entered the room whilst this person with the black object was in that room, black plastic object?
Mr Chairman, when I put my head around the door, I didn't see him in the room.
Did he indicate to you that he was leaving to go and buy food and that you should accompany him?
Mr Chairman, my recollection is that he said that he would be going to buy food and I thought it appropriate to go and buy food for my people as well.
Mr Baker, could you give us an indication as to - you said that you put your head around the door on more than one occasion, approximately how many times did you do that?
Mr Chairman, I think if I recollect, I said a couple of times.
I presume I think not longer than five minutes, between each poking my head in.
Mr Samuel, if you will just allow me, sorry, Mr Chair, now I have lost my train of thought, when Col Taylor left, you did not know that it was Ms Khubeka in that room?
And when you poked your head around the door, did you know who was in the room?
I did not know who it was.
But you were expecting a terrorist?
Did you think that was a terrorist?
I saw a very obese woman sitting there.
Mr Chairman, in the past, there has been female terrorists as well as male terrorists.  I wasn't sure what they had there.
As far as you were concerned, it was the terrorist?
That is when I enquired and they said no, they hadn't arrested the terrorists.
Sorry, sorry Chairperson, just - you have said a couple of times you poked your head around there, can you try and be more specific?
Mr Chairman, a couple is twice.
Only twice, is my recollection of poking my head around the corner.
Sir, you told this Commission that you heard blows coming from inside the room?
I take it then that within five minutes of her arrival, Ms Khubeka was being beaten?
What time did you go to sleep Capt Baker, Mr Baker?
Mr Chairman, I cannot recall that.
Was it after all the other members had left Winkelspruit base?
Did you notice when the last member left the base?
Mr Chairman, I cannot remember that.
Who was the last person you saw leaving the base sir?
Mr Chairman, I am afraid I cannot answer that, I didn't know the order of the people leaving the base,  who left when and how and what.
I am enquiring as to who you saw last leave the base.
Mr Chairman, as I have said, I didn't see people driving out.
So basically you do not know whether people were at the base or they had all left by that stage, when you went to sleep?

Mr Chairman, Mr Coetzer came to me and said that he was taking the people back to C.R. Swart and I heard vehicles leaving and that was obviously my people, but the other people that left, I am not sure who left when.
Your primary purpose to go to this base was to enquire as to what your people were doing, and how their operations were going, am I right?
In this regard, you spoke to Mr Taylor?
Did Mr Taylor tell you how it came about that Ms Khubeka was at the base?
Mr Chairman, at the time that I spoke to Mr Taylor, he was still expecting terrorists to arrive at the base.
I see, so when Mr Botha arrived with a terrorist, you were relieved, am I right?
You, because your wait was over now, you were waiting for terrorists to arrive, am I right, or your members, the askaris, to arrive, am I right?  Were you not relieved sir, that the wait was over?
I cannot recall having such an emotion, Mr Chairman.
Did you approach the kombi when Mr Baker, Mr Botha arrived with the others?
And how long after the vehicle, the kombi arrived with Mr Botha, did you speak to Mr Botha, if you had spoken to him?
I spoke to him when he was already in the room, it was a couple of minutes, I cannot say how many seconds, minutes, but it wasn't a long period.
I asked him if it is positive if he had terrorists and that is when he informed me that it wasn't a terrorist, it was the contact woman.
Did he tell you that your askari had made a mistake, sir?
Mr Chairman, they hadn't arrested, I think who they were waiting for, so they had obviously just got second best.
Did he inform you that he had sent your askari, members of your Unit out to arrest certain persons and they had brought an informer, another person in?
The contact person whom they did not expect to see, sir?
Mr Chairman, my people were not sent to arrest anybody.

I think what Mr Samuel is putting to you is that the intention was for MK cadres to be arrested, particularly the leader of a unit, and the askaris were sent in for that purpose, that is why they had arranged a rendezvous point at Battery Beach, etc, hoping to catch at least the leader of the Unit and in stead of that, your member or members, bring in the contact person which we all know, resulted in the termination of the particular operation?   What Mr Samuel wants to know is, did Botha tell you about that or talk to you about that happening, that event happening which led to the termination of the operation?
Mr Chairman, yes, we did discuss it after the event, we did discuss it.  We had to discuss the viability of the operation continuing or not, which is when we decided that it should be terminated.
That discussion, did it take place that night or the next day or the day after that?
As far as I can remember, that night and we discussed it again the next day.
Thank you.  Did Mr Botha tell you that the askaris had made a blunder in bringing in the contact woman?
Mr Chairman, I assume so because it was a blunder.
Can you remember, you are just assuming now?
No, it is an assumption, I cannot remember the details of all discussions we had.
Were you present when the body was removed from the room, sir?
Mr Chairman, I did not see the body being removed and I did not see who removed it.
Sorry Mr Samuel, did you see the body at all?
Did you see the vehicle that was used to remove the body?
So sir, I put it to you you cannot truthfully tell this Commission that Jimmy Mbane was not in the verandah at the time when the body was being removed?
Mr Chairman, I am not sure where he was at that stage.
So it is possible that he was in the vicinity, sir at the time when the body was being removed?
That is a possibility, I do not know where he was.
So your earlier speculation that all your members had left with Mr Coetzer, is mere speculation, am I right?
Mr Chairman, Mr Coetzer did take the members, Mr Coetzer was taking the members back to C.R. Swart, he wouldn't have left anybody behind.

Sir, since this issue has been pushed, may I refer you to Mr Coetzer, sorry Mr van der Westhuizen's statement, Exhibit F, page 3, paragraph 9.  It says here on the fourth line
"... indeed, we would sleep there some evenings."
Mr Chairman, it looked as if people had been sleeping at the base.

And he says, he goes on further and says
"... some of the askaris also stayed there during their visit upon this occasion."
	He is referring to the time on this occasion, am I right, I am not too good with Afrikaans, but that is the way I understand it?  Is he telling a lie?

Mr Chairman, I cannot comment on the other days that the operation was running, if people had stayed there or not.  All I can comment on is the time that I was there, which was that evening, and that evening Mr Coetzer said he was taking them back to C.R. Swart.
Was that after you arrived back with the food?
But you didn't see them go out, you don't know whether he took them all or not?
Mr Chairman, he came and discussed it with me and I told him that it would be better to take them back to C.R. Swart after this incident.
Thank you Mr Chairman.   Do you know whether Mr Radebe had already left the base with Mr Coetzer?
Mr Chairman, Mr Coetzer would have had a vehicle and Mr Radebe would have had a vehicle, they would have both left in their vehicles.
If Mr Radebe says that he was sleeping in the kombi at the base, will he be mistaken about that sir?
Mr Chairman, he could have been, while they were waiting, he could have been sitting sleeping in the vehicle, these people have been as I understood it, working long hours.
But if it were to be said, we don't know, but if it were to be said that he slept there, correct me if I am wrong, for the whole night?
At the base in the kombi?
No, that Mr Chairman, I would perceive to be incorrect because Mr Coetzer had an instruction that they should go back to C.R. Swart.

You see, earlier you and again I made a note of this, you said yes, you remember talking to Coetzer and after speaking to him, you heard his vehicle leave.  You only speak about one vehicle at that point in time, leaving, not about vehicles in the plural?  We now hear that Radebe in fact had his own vehicle?
Mr Chairman, that is so.  The evidence was given, he had a kombi and Mr Coetzer had if I can recall correct, a blue truck.
Yes, and Mbane was also driving a Corolla we have been told?
Mr Chairman, that is correct, but it was not our vehicle.
Yes, but the point is these people had access to all these vehicles, at least two that the askari or Radebe had and clearly Coetzer must have had his own vehicle as well?
That is correct, Coetzer had his own vehicle.
So it is not like a convoy of vehicles left, you only heard one vehicle leave at that point?
Mr Chairman, as I have said, I am not sure when they left and how did they leave and so on, but the instruction was that they would leave and they wouldn't have stayed.
Yes.  That was your instruction to Coetzer, whether he relayed it onwards, you don't know?
Well, I assume that he did Mr Chairman, I don't think he would have disobeyed me  Mr Chairman.
Mr Baker, if Mr Mbane says he did not go with Mr Coetzer, but spent the night there, what would you say to that?
Mr Chairman, I doubt whether they would have left him behind.
Yes, but you didn't see Mbane, but he may have been there?
I didn't see him there the morning Mr Chairman.
He wasn't there in the morning, Mr Chairman.
Yes.  So you are saying that as far as you are concerned, he must have gone with Mr Coetzer?
Mr Chairman, Mr Coetzer and his team weren't there the next morning.
Did you look for Mr Mbane the next morning?
Mr Chairman, as far as I can remember, we met them at C.R. Swart the next day.
My question to you sir, did you look for Mr Mbane the next morning?
I did not look for him, because he was not there Mr Chairman.
Sir, did you look for him?  Is your answer you did not look for him or that you looked for him and he wasn't there?
Mr Chairman, surely he has answered the question by now.
Well, I think if Mr Samuel wants to, he didn't answer it directly, the question was did you look for Mbane the next morning at the base?
I did not look for him at the base, because he was not there Mr Chairman.
And you don't know what time, if Mr Mbane spent the night at tle base, you would not know what time he had left, am I right?  There were vehicles available to him, am I right?

Mr Chairman, the driver of the kombi was Mr Radebe, he was in charge of the kombi, he wouldn't have left the kombi for Mr Mbane to drive around in.  There are specific instructions in that regard that the group leaders would drive the vehicles.
Was Mr Radebe there the next morning?
Do you know what time Mr Radebe left the base?
Mr Chairman, I do not know what time the people left the base.
Sir, you have given evidence that you heard shots being, someone being hit.
Thank you Mr Chairman, thank you, I just didn't get the word, you heard blows whilst you were outside the room, you heard blows, is that correct?
These blows must have been quite severe for you to hear it outside the room?

Mr Chairman, they were muted blows, I think most of us were at school at the same time, I remember standing outside the Headmaster's office and listening to colleagues getting a hiding before I got a hiding, it is about hearing a chap getting caned.
When you heard them, the door would have been closed?
The door was closed Mr Chairman, but I did hear that she was receiving blows and I also heard exclamations as a result of the blows.
Basically you heard screams sir, is that correct?
Shouts, exclamations as you would if you received a blow.
I mean from that you can assume two things, one thing that they were painful otherwise the person wouldn't be calling out?
And number two that they were of such a nature that they were hard enough for you to hear them outside?
Mr Botha, was it Mr Botha or Mr Taylor that informed you that Ms Khubeka had died?
My recollection is that it was Mr Botha.
And then did you all leave the scene thereafter, the room?
I wasn't in the room when Mr Botha, which room are you referring to, Mr Chair?
Where Ms Khubeka was being held?
I wasn't informed in that room, Mr Chairman.
Were you informed at the place where you slept for the night, that building with the tent over it?
If my recollection is correct, when we stopped the vehicle, I think Mr Botha came to Mr du Preez and said that Ms Khubeka had died, this is where I heard it.
And I assume thereafter everyone had left the base, am I right, all the white members had left the base?
What is your reply to that?
Except yourself you mean, or were there still other white members at the base?
I think he said earlier that Mr Coetzer left only after he came back with the food.
Thank you.  Sir, we know for a fact that the black members would not sleep with the white members, am I right?
Mr Chairman, that is why they went back to C.R. Swart Square.
Please just answer the question, sir.  Is that a fact that the white members would sleep separately from the black members?
Generally they slept separately in the same vicinity.
If the white members had to sleep in the building under the tent which we had seen, or was pointed out to us in the in loco inspection, where would the black members sleep sir?
Mr Chairman, as I said, at my time at the base, the black members did not sleep at that base, I cannot say where they would have slept.
Are there any other facilities that you had seen, have you been on that in loco inspection sir?

The areas being pointed out to you at the in loco inspection, is there any other place convenient place, besides the verandah or one of those rooms, that any person could sleep except of course in a car, I am talking about a building?
As I understand there was another facility which has been broken down, which was on the other side of the verandah.

No such facility was pointed out.  Sir, I put it to you that it would have been more convenient and in fact, the only place for a person to sleep is either on the verandah of the building where Ms Khubeka was held, or in one of the rooms if same was available?
I should imagine sleeping in the kombi would have probably been more comfortable.
I didn't get your answer, sir.
I should imagine sleeping in the kombi, would have been even more comfortable than on the cement.
But it is possible that members could use that area to sleep in?
It is possible, Mr Chairman.  They could sleep anywhere.
Sir, I refer to your affidavit, did you know who removed the body, sir?  Did Capt Botha tell you who he instructed to remove the body?
So you had no idea that Mr Wasserman and Mr du Preez had removed the body?
No Mr Chairman, I heard that here.
How did you know that it was Capt Botha who decided that her body should be removed and placed elsewhere?
Because Capt Botha informed me of the fact that he had decided that the body should be removed and placed elsewhere.
Sir, Jimmy Mbane will say, sorry before I put Mr Jimmy Mbane's version to you, did you notice whether Ms Khubeka was tied by her hands and her feet or her hands and her feet were tied?
Sir, Mr Jimmy Mbane will say that on instructions from either Mr Botha or Mr Taylor, he had handed over Ms Khubeka to them at the Battery Beach, which you would not know about?
That is correct Mr Chairman, I don't know what his instructions were.
He will say that whilst he was at the base at Winkelspruit, he had noticed Ms Khubeka blindfolded, tied, both hands and feet?
I cannot comment on that Mr Chairman, I do not recollect.
He will say that whilst he was at the base, the only place he could sleep and he slept for the night, was on the verandah next to the room where Ms Khubeka was being held and interrogated?
Mr Chairman, I dispute that, it could have been in the kombi, and they did, they were instructed to leave the base that night and go and sleep at C.R. Swart Square.
Sir, he will say that whilst he was at the base, he had heard Ms Khubeka scream almost continuously because she was in his words, interrogated and tortured.
Mr Chairman, I cannot comment on that, I heard a couple of shouts and I was only there for a very short while.
Your evidence is that Mr Myeza was not present at the base when you got there?
Mr Jimmy Mbane will say that Mr Myeza, Mr  Lauwrie and Mr Coetzer in fact had removed this body from the base?
Lauwrie, I think he is referring to Mr Wasserman?
Mr Wasserman, Lauwrie Wasserman I think.
Mr Chairman, I don't know who removed the body from the base, I heard it here.
Sir, if Mr Taylor had made any payments to the askaris, would you have known about it?
Mr Chairman, I don't think Mr Taylor would have made payments to the askaris.
The question was, if he had, would you know about it or would you expect to have been informed?
I should have known about it, Mr Chairman.
Thank you.  Did Mr Taylor tell you of all payments that he made to askaris?
Mr Chairman, the askaris did not fall under Mr Taylor for administrative purposes and payments made to askaris, it would be made by Head Office, not by Mr Taylor.
So you would not know if Mr Taylor had paid the askaris, am I right, if he did not inform you about it?
If he hadn't informed me about it, I assume he wouldn't have done it.
Would it have been irregular for him to have paid them?
Mr Chairman, applications for rewards would have to be made to Head Office and it would be highly irregular for Port Natal to ask for a reward for a person who is in any case based at Head Office.
Do you know whether Mr Mbane was in fact paid for the part he played in this operation, the normal, we have heard often about the rewards, was Mr Mbane paid for the part he played?
Mr Chairman, I am not sure, I cannot give a positive or negative, he could have been paid, he could not have been paid, I am not sure.
Would it be possible, if he was paid, that the payment, although it came from your section, C-Section, Head Office, that it could have been affected by Mr Taylor?
That he could have made a recommendation?
No, that he could have paid it for you?
I doubt Mr Chairman, because the people were removed back to Pretoria two days after the operation.
Mr Mbane will deny that he slept at C.R. Swart Dog Unit on that evening.
Mr Chairman, the instruction was that they should sleep there, and they weren't there the next morning.

No further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR SAMUEL
Thank you.  I think this would be a convenient time to take the tea adjournment, Mr Wills?

Yes, thank you, Mr Chairperson, I would like to make a request that the applicant who is testifying presently, sit across there, I do find it difficult to cross-examine without having sight of the witness.  I don't think that will inconvenience anybody too much.

Yes, I think we can do this, it is not unreasonable.  If we can just make the arrangements during the tea interval.  Thank you, we will take the short tea adjournment until half past eleven.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
C. BAKER: (s.u.o.)

Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr Baker, you counsel tells us that your affidavit that appears, your second affidavit that appears at the back of Bundle 2, is an improved version on the application that commences at page 91 of the first Bundle.  I have had an opportunity to peruse these two and it appears to me that the only improvement that I can see is the fact that the second one is signed in 1999, is that correct, and the first one is unsigned?
So they are identical apart from the fact that the latter application is signed in 1999, on the 22nd of June 1999, is that correct?
Sorry, are you saying that the one in Volume 1 is signed on the 5th of May 1997?
Mr Chairperson, sorry, my copy that I got from the TRC is not signed.  I've got ...
My copy is on page 120, it is signed the 5th of May 1997, signed at Pretoria Central.
That is not my application Mr chairperson.
Sorry Mr Chairperson, it is in fact signed on page 112, I am misleading the witness slightly, but it isn't commissioned.
It is dated, it is not commissioned, yes.  That is improved in that respect?

Mr Chairman, maybe I must just assist here to make it clearer for Mr Wills.   This, I don't know how this copy landed in the hands of the TRC because quite clearly you can see, we were still improving on it, I don't know how it got to the TRC, but this was something that was compiled during 1997 and then the subsequent application was then signed and commissioned on the 22nd day of June 1999.
In other words the application actually was attested to after the cut-off date for applications, is that correct, which I believe was the 10th of May 1997?
The final cut-off date was the 30th of September 1997, there were various extensions and the very last one, there was one in May, but the very last one was the 30th of September 1997.
I am indebted to you Mr Chairperson, be that as it may, this application was signed after the cut-off, the final cut-off day of the 30th of September 1997.
Attested to Mr Chairman, yes, that is correct.
Are there any other improvements or is it an identical document?
Mr Chairman, on the document that was referred to, there are a number of handwritten improvements that I did, just more spelling mistakes.
Oh, I see.  Okay, but essentially is the substance the same except for typographical errors?

So I must assume that you were carefully applying your mind to this matter from as your counsel tells us in 1997 and then you looked through it carefully at that stage and you made those corrections, is that correct?  When did you make those corrections to this draft, I am talking about the handwriting changes on for example page 109 and 110?
Mr Chairman, I am not sure when I made those corrections.
But I mean what year was it?  You don't know?
If you don't know, tell me you don't know.
I cannot say exactly when I did it, Mr Chairman.
It might also have been in 1999?

Mr Chairman, I think I have to explain here, my lawyer is in Port Elizabeth, I am in Pretoria, so the documents were brought up to me when he was representing other people and given to me to read through, to sign and to take back again.
I must assume that prior to your signing this in June 1999, that you read it very carefully?
Mr Chairman, I went through the document.
And as far as you are concerned, this is the most accurate recollection that you have of the incident that pertained on that day?

Now, did you have any reason to omit from your application the fact that you heard these screams and you were convinced, or the shouts as you described them, and you were aware of the fact that the deceased was being beaten?
No Mr Chairman, I had no reason to do that.
You were aware of the need for full disclosure?
Mr Chairman, I am aware that giving evidence before this Commission, I must make a full disclosure.
And you thought that even in the light of your awareness of the need for full disclosure, you thought that that wasn't an important detail to put into your application?
Mr Chairman, I am aware that I must make a full disclosure as the Act implies, in front of this Commission, in person.
So you thought that you only needed to fully disclose in person, it didn't matter if you didn't fully disclose in your application, is that what you are saying?
So therefore your application in paper, and that version that we see that was signed in June, is not a full disclosure?

Now, I want to turn and look at that quite carefully, before I start, I just want to try and establish the date that as far as you can remember,when you arrived in the Winkelspruit base.  You said I think it was the first time that you had been to Winkelspruit, so you should have some sort of recollection of when that was.
Mr Chairman, as I said in my initial application, I wasn't sure of the date, whether it was 1987 or 1988.
You cannot even remember the year?
You say 1987 or 1988, that is the most accurate that you can put it to?
That is contained in my document, yes Mr Chairman.
Okay, now we know that you were at Winkelspruit base prior to the arrival of the deceased in this matter?
What caused you to go there?
Mr Chairman, I had to go and see Col Taylor with regards to the deployment of the other teams as well.
You say as well, what else?
Mr Chairman, I had two teams there, the team under who I presume was Mr McCarter and then Mr Coetzer's team.
Yes, now I would assume that you being a senior officer, and your job being to supervise, no doubt, to supervise in the sense that you wanted to check that your men were doing their job properly?

Mr Chairman, I was there to find out from the people under whom they were working, if they were satisfied with the work that they were doing, and to coordinate with them and to see that for further deployment, what was required, whether they would require people the following month and so on, that used to be my task.
Yes, would you ever be involved in discussions with those deploying your people as regards the tasks which they put to those persons who were from Vlakplaas?
That is so Mr Chairman, on this occasion I also did so.
Yes, I would imagine that particularly in view of your seniority, you would have quite detailed discussions and you would contribute to the planning process?

Mr Chairman, I could make suggestions as regards my people and the nature of the people to be used, people from which areas, if I may explain in more detail here, what generally happened was that the Division requiring the services of an askari unit, would generally have information as to who they expected to be in the area.  Then we would find out and go through the documentation to see which askaris knew the people that would come, so that they could make a visual identification, because that was their purpose.  Then we would try and send the best possible team to the area as requested and that used to be a fairly formidable task to ascertain which people to send to which area to obtain the best results.

Yes, and no doubt on the occasion of this operation, your mere attendance in Durban and your mere, the fact that you were having discussions with Col Taylor, would indicate that you were quite deeply involved in the planning of this operation?

Mr Chairman, in this matter the Intelligence operation of Capt Botha was an operation of which I did not have detailed knowledge.  The knowledge I got, was the day that I spoke to Col Taylor, the afternoon when I got to Winkelspruit.
Okay, so you spoke to Taylor that afternoon when you got to Winkelspruit.  What time, or how long prior to the arrival of the deceased, did you arrive at Winkelspruit?
Mr Chairman, as I recalled earlier, it was in the afternoon and it could have been an hour, an hour or two at the most.
And then, Taylor was there when you arrived?
Mr Chairman, as I recall, he met me on the highway to guide me to the place, I did not know how to get there on my own.
Yes, so in other words for that hour or two you spent with Mr Taylor awaiting the arrival of certain persons, not so?
You were expecting as others, that certain persons were going to be brought to the base to be interrogated, is that correct?

Now, in the light of your obvious concession that you considered your application seriously, prior to signing it, I am wanting to put to you that how you tried to testify earlier, ie about this being a sort of bundled operation and the wrong person being arrested, is actually incorrect and I want to quote because your evidence is actually consistent with Mr Taylor, your evidence is consistent with Mr Coetzer, your evidence is consistent with Mr, should I say your statement, I am referring to here is consistent with Mr Mbane, and Mr Radebe because you say
"...  the purpose of the operation was to arrest four MK members who were to infiltrate from Swaziland and report at the facility."
	I am quoting from page 156.  Do you agree?
Well, that is common cause, that is what you say.

You then go on to say p
"...  the askari had to determine when they would arrive."
	The important problem that I have, is your next sentence where you say -
"... after six weeks the cadres had not arrived and the askari's version of events was being questioned by Capt Botha."
	In other words that implies to me that at that stage, Capt Botha had come to the realisation as has been the testimony previously of others, that the askaris weren't capable of doing their jobs?
Mr Chairman, as I have said in my evidence, this is what was relayed to me by Col Taylor.  I cannot comment on it.

Sorry, if I could just put one point on this before I forget, Mr Wills.   I have heard in various hearings Mr Baker, that the usual practice was to deploy your people, C1 people, askaris and others, usually for a period of three weeks to wherever, be it Boksburg, Jozini, Durban, wherever, and then they would come back to Vlakplaas for about a week and then teams would be deployed again.  After six weeks, that is now getting quite long, isn't it, it is an unusual length of time for a deployment?
Mr Chairman, yes, they had been there for an extended period.
I just wanted to know that, that was unusual, it wasn't the normal sort of in for three weeks, back again out?

Just to be clear, Mr Baker, I am asking you what was in your mind, I realise that this was in the context of your discussion with Taylor, but from what you have said here, it indicates that Taylor conveyed to you that the askaris had not done their job in the sense that they hadn't yet after some time, identified the four MK cadres and as a consequence of that, it was decided and this is what Taylor is referring to here, that the woman who was supposed to have given the askaris that information, would be arrested for interrogation?  That is how I read this?

Mr Chairman, I feel that if they were to have arrested the woman, there wouldn't have been, or picked up the woman, there wouldn't have been a necessity of getting her at Battery Beach, they could have brought her directly to the facility, because he had befriended the woman.

Sorry, can you answer my question with respect?  As I understand your English that you use here, there is only one implication that the four people, the information regarding the four freedom fighters was not coming quickly enough to Taylor or to Botha and as a result of that, the action had to be shortcut and in order to get this information, it was decided to arrest the woman?
That is not so Mr Chairman.  I wasn't aware of instructions to the askaris before they left.

What Mr Wills is putting to you is from the way it is stated, from that sentence commencing "after six weeks" through to "Amanzimtoti", the last two sentences of the first paragraph or second paragraph on page 156, what Mr Wills is putting to you is would you agree that an interpretation of what is stated there, is that after six weeks, Mr Botha became impatient or had the feeling that the askaris weren't being  effective in achieving their intended objective of getting these four cadres and therefore the deceased was brought in, Ms Khubeka was brought in.  That is what he is saying if you read that, just take a look at those two sentences and see what interpretation you can put on those two sentences.

Mr Chairman, as I have stated that this is what was told to me by Mr Taylor, that the version was being questioned by Capt Botha because the person was not forthcoming and then the very next sentence, that the askari had gone to meet with her and that she was apprehended by Capt Botha and his team and brought to the base near Amanzimtoti.  Actually what I have done there is I have shortened the whole version.
So what you are saying now is what Mr Wills, you don't agree with what Mr Wills put to you about the interpretation of this?
Mr Chairman, I mean he can interpret it in that way, I cannot say what the instructions were prior to that, if he interprets it as such, Mr Wills, that is his interpretation.

You see what is very strange to me, nowhere in your affidavit do you say that anybody was the slightest bit surprised when this woman arrived.  Why is that, that would have been something that I would have put if that had been the original plan?

Mr Chairman, I cannot comment on the people's reaction as to what they have done, I don't know what they were expecting at that stage.  I myself was expecting a terrorist, and I didn't - I saw this woman, I only heard she was not a terrorist when I was told she was not a terrorist.
Where do you say that in your application?
I didn't say it in my application, Mr Wills, it came out during examination.

I put it to you that you are not being truthful with us.  I put it to you that you have heard the evidence of your four colleagues and you are just trying to support them and as a result you are not telling the truth, because that isn't what your statement says at all.
Mr Chairman, I think that is Mr Wills' interpretation.
Well, it seems to be also Mr Coetzer's interpretation.  No doubt as a senior officer, you would also have dealings with Mr Coetzer, not so?  He was your immediate subordinate?
And you would find out exactly what he was doing in the operation, you would know that?
Mr Chairman, as I said earlier, I had not seen Mr Coetzer prior to  Ms Khubeka arriving at the base.  I hadn't yet spoken to him.

Well, let me tell you what Mr Coetzer says in paragraph 7 of his affidavit, it is somewhere after page 101.  Mr Coetzer says that the plan was, sorry
"... I was informed by one of the members of the Security Branch, that the leader of the ANC cell which had been infiltrated by Jimmy Mbane, was a woman.   The plan was to interrogate her."
	So you disagree?
Sorry Mr Wills, just for record purposes, page 102, paragraph 7.
Mr Chairman, I cannot comment on Mr Coetzer's recollection.  As I say, I did not know what the instructions were prior to her being arrested.
Sorry Mr Baker, if I may Mr Wills, what you would concede is that Coetzer would be closer to the operation than you?
And he would have a much closer working knowledge of what actually happened on that day?
That is correct Mr Chairman, he was part of the operation.

Thank you, from another tack and relying on your expertise in these various activities, it seems to me that if the askaris were not being successful in the sense that they were getting the information about the four ANC infiltrators, or they weren't getting the identities, the information wasn't coming through as your affidavit, and I stress your affidavit, indicates, then one would have to do something about that, wouldn't that be so, and there would be I think as Mr Lax has put to a previous witness, one of those things would be to arrest the woman in order to get the information yourselves?  Wouldn't that be so?
Well, let's try and take it a little bit further than that, assuming the askaris were unsuccessful, would you leave the woman and not do anything to her and ignore this vital source of information?
Mr Chairman, I cannot comment on what the local operators would have done, I mean there are various options - one is to arrest the woman and apprehend her.

I am asking you, I am not asking about the local operators, I am asking you in the capacity as a senior Security Branch personnel with expertise in these activities, what would you do assuming the askaris were unsuccessful in getting the information, you know this woman is living in a house, you know exactly where she is, what would you do?

Well, number one, tap her telephone.  I assume they had informers that were also in on her and to keep Intelligence operations running in the hope that these people could be apprehended, but I would have withdrawn those askaris at that stage.

You would have, with respect, you would have withdrawn the askaris and arrest the woman?  Particularly if, as your sentence indicates, time is of the essence, you cannot wait another six weeks?  What do you do if you cannot wait another six weeks?  You are worried about another bomb going off at McGoo's Bar?
That is a question, yes, if time was of the essence, what do you do?
Mr Chairman, I am being asked what I would have done.
And I have already said that if you had exhausted all your information capabilities, then I would concede, to arrest the person and interrogate them.
Yes, thank you.  I put it to you that this is what happened here, and you know that?  Do you want to comment?
Mr Chairman, I did not know that beforehand.  I did not know what the instructions were.
What did you talk to Mr Taylor about in the two hours that you waited or the one to two hours that you waited?

Mr Chairman, as far as I can remember, we discussed the deployment of askaris, the future deployment of askaris and at that stage, Mr Taylor was also considering starting his own Unit in Natal, because they felt that the situation was such that they couldn't wait for us to send teams down every time and there was always a break between deployments and they felt that this was hampering their activities.
Did you not talk about this operation that was, the fact that there was somebody that was going to be brought in for questioning?
Mr Chairman, as I have mentioned before, we discussed that, that is where I got this information as stated in my statement.

Yes, because it is completely consistent with Taylor's version, and I put that to you from page 4 of his affidavit and that he says, I am referring to page 4 of Bundle 1, the last paragraph, he says
"... at a later stage an askari, Jimmy Mbane.
Can we just get the statement.

He says and to quote
"... at a later stage an askari, Jimmy Mbane, informed us that he had arranged that the Khubeka woman would be brought to us at the old Railway Police shooting range near Winkelspruit."
	He was waiting for the Khubeka woman?

He in fact goes on to say Mr Wills, that
"... I recall that I, myself, was present there on the day waiting for the arrival of the Khubeka woman."

He must have informed you of this, and that is why you have worded your affidavit in the manner you have?  You weren't waiting for four terrorists, for the leader of some terrorists which no one has given us any information about?  You were waiting for the arrival of the Khubeka woman and you knew that?
No Mr Chairman, I was not waiting for anybody.
What were you doing there, didn't you know anybody was coming?

I wasn't part of the Intelligence gathering operation, I was there to meet with them on other matters concerning the askaris, this is what he informed me of, which is in my affidavit, which I have stated.  This is my recollection of it.
But don't you think, wouldn't you at least do me the service of conceding that what is said in his affidavit is completely consistent with what you have said in your affidavit?
I will concede that Mr Chairman.
Yes, so you have the same version on paper?  Thank you.

So, now the other important aspect of your affidavit is that you use the words and Mr Visser has referred you to this, you use the words and I am quoting from the second paragraph, the second sentence of the second paragraph on page 156, you say
"...during the questioning by Capt Botha, I went in and out to establish whether there was any information on the four MK cadres."
	My understanding of English is that there is only one interpretation of that and that is that Capt Botha was questioning the suspect.

Mr Chairman, I spoke to Capt Botha when I put my head through the door.   Capt Botha informed me what was going on, I was not in the room during the interrogation, I cannot say who was doing the questioning.

Why do you say that under oath in your application then?  Why don't you say, I mean if you had told us that in the beginning, you would have started this paragraph off, "I don't know, I wasn't in the room, I don't know who did the questioning", but that is not what you say, you say precisely the opposite.  You say
"... during the questioning by Capt Botha ..."
	can you explain that?
Mr Chairman, he was part of the team that was busy interrogating her.
I assume the people in the room were questioning her and that is why I stated it that way, because this was his operation.

Well, again, coincidentally Mr Coetzer tells us that the black woman was then being interrogated mainly by Botha and Taylor, so - and I am referring to page 10, I think, I mean paragraph 10 which I presume might be on page 102.
Thank you Mr Chairperson, do you see that?  Why would Coetzer say that if that wasn't so?  Why would you say this if it wasn't so?
Mr Chairman, as I say, I assumed he was busy questioning her, because he was there.
So do you want us, are you essentially applying for a variation of your amnesty application to read "during the questioning, I assume by Capt Botha", is that what you wanting me to say now?
Otherwise "during the questioning by Capt Botha and others".
I put it to you, you are changing your version, but I will proceed.
That is not so, Mr Chairman.

When after the - sorry, I retract that, you say here you went in and out to establish whether there was any information on the four cadres, that too, I put it to you supports exactly what I was saying earlier, about the purpose of the operation was to arrest Khubeka in order to question her in order to give information about these cadres, so you went there to find out whether that interrogation had been successful, is that not so?
I put my head through the door to find out if there was any information on it, that is so.
You went in and out, you said twice?
Now, was the first time you went in before the questioning started or had the questioning already commenced?
Mr Chairman, I assume the questioning had already commenced, the people were in the room with her.
And then how long after the questioning had commenced, did you put your head in for the first time?
Mr Chairman, I assume it was a couple of minutes, it wouldn't have been very long.
Had she screamed yet or shouted?  Had you heard the whip, the water pipe or the shambok, whatever?
Yes, I think I had before going in.
